title-group.article-title: Simulation of macro and micro journal bearings: Using the Lattice Boltzmann Method

abstract.p: Numerical simulation of macro and micro journal bearings is investigated using Lattice Boltzmann Method. Bounce-back boundary condition is applied in macro flow simulation and a combination of diffuse scattering and bounce-back techniques is used in micro calculations. An approximation method which is called ghost boundary is employed to simulate the wall curvature of macro and micro bearings. The Lattice Boltzmann Method solutions of two classic configurations are compared with the numerical solution of the Reynolds equations. Bearing cavitation is approached in a simplified way for a macro journal bearing and the results are compared with a finite element solution. The Lattice Boltzmann Method results are satisfactory for the investigated problem. A computational analysis is also used to simulate the complicated behavior of the micro journal bearings in the slip flow regime with Knudsen number varying between 0.01 and 0.05. The working fluid in micro simulations is gas. In order to model the interaction between gas and solid walls, a local boundary condition which is derived from the kinetic theory of gases using multiple relaxation time method is employed and the static performance of the micro bearing is analyzed. Applying the second-order velocity boundary condition, the pressure distributions obtained from the Lattice Boltzmann Method are successfully compared with the results of spectral collocation method. Results indicate that by increasing Knudsen number the maximum of pressure decreases.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The present work deals with the application of Lattice Boltzmann Method (LBM) for thin-film lubrication with suitable boundary conditions. Manufacturing processes of machines with small dimensions have greatly developed in recent years. Such small machines are often used as sensors for pressure, temperature, mass flow, velocity, acceleration and sound. They are also used to calculate vertical and horizontal movements as well as a simple member of micro heat pumps or micro heat engines. Micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) are devices with a characteristic length of more than 1 µm and less than 1 mm. They have both mechanical and electrical components. Well understanding of these devices is required to create them and to analyze their behavior for further optimization purposes.

Gas-lubricated bearings are used in rotating machines with high speed. Some advantages of these bearings are low friction loss, low operating noise and minimal temperature limitation and maintenance needs. The most important characteristic of the gas-lubricated micro journal bearings is their performance in high-speed operations, which becomes a significant point in their optimization. Kim et al.1 designed and fabricated gas micro bearings with deep X-ray lithography and electroplating and calculated the performances of micro bearings in terms of load parameters and attitude angles using the theory of molecular gas lubrication (MGL). Their results indicated that the radial clearance ratio of the micro-journal bearing is large while the bearing eccentricity ratio would be about 0.9 in order to maintain stability. Consequently, molecular effects are not negligible and stability consideration must be concurrent with a high operating eccentricity. Traditionally, the classical Reynolds equation has been applied to analyze and model gas-lubricated journal micro bearings. Piekos and Breuer2 studied the stability of a hydrodynamic journal bearing in a micro-gas turbine using pseudo-spectral orbit simulation. They indicated that the Reynolds equation is suitable for the analysis of gas-lubricated journal micro bearing. Orr3 applied a macro-scale model to investigate the characteristics of a gas-lubricated journal bearing in a micro-gas turbine and found that there was not only whirl but also radial instability in extremely short gas bearings. Zhang and Shan4 investigated the dynamic performance of gas micro bearings in microsystems and found that the load-carrying capacity of the journal bearing with low aspect ratio is linearly proportional to its bearing number. Liu et al.5 presented a new analytical model, which contains a fluid dynamic model for axial flow gas-lubricated journal bearings and a rotor dynamic model for micro bearings. In addition, Boedo and Booker6 proposed a new finite element elasto hydrodynamic (EHD) lubrication analysis appropriate for gas-lubricated journal bearings using dynamic conditions.

Slip effects are significant for gas flows in close spacing and appropriate corrections to the Reynolds equation are required. The level of rarefaction effect could be represented by the Knudsen number Kn, defined as the ratio of the molecular mean free path λ to the minimum spacing h. A wide range of Knudsen numbers is possible in gas-lubricated micro bearings, but the slip flow regime with 10−3 ≤ Kn ≤ 0.1 is the most frequent one. The eccentricity ratio of gas-lubricated journal micro bearings used in micro-rotating machinery often varies from 0.5 to 0.9 and the local Knudsen number at the minimum film thickness changes between 0.011 and 0.053,7 which falls into the slip-flow regime. Analytical and numerical researches have been carried out on the slip gas flows in micro bearings. Maureau et al.8 studied the characteristics of eccentric gas-lubricated journal micro bearings of infinite length. However, the gas-lubricated journal bearings in micro-rotating machinery have a different regime as distinguished from the conventional ones. For some special applications such as micro-gas turbine, the gas-lubricated journal bearing should operate at high temperature condition.7

It is accepted that velocity slip is essential in micro flows therefore, the velocity inversion phenomenon may also occur in a micro-scale cylindrical flow under some conditions. The velocity slip phenomenon has been studied using different approaches. The first approach is to solve the Navier–Stokes equations with certain no-slip boundary conditions. A number of slip boundary conditions have been used for flows with curved walls. For instance, Einzel, Panzer and Liu (EPL)9,10 proposed a generalized slip boundary condition in which the surface curvature effect was incorporated. The EPL formulation was developed mainly for continuum flows over rough walls. Later, Tibbs et al.11 related the EPL formulation to wall accommodation coefficients so that it can be also applied to rarefied gas flows.

The second approach in the study of velocity slip phenomenon of the cylindrical Couette flow is based on the solution of the Boltzmann equation. Under the diffuse-specular reflection boundary condition, Aoki et al.12 performed a detailed asymptotic analysis of the Boltzmann equation, and investigated the cylindrical Couette flow in both near continuum and free-molecular cases. Aoki et al.12 also analyzed the flow behavior in the whole range of Knudsen numbers by solving the Boltzmann-BGK equation using the finite-difference method. Direct simulations using the Monte Carlo (DSMC) method, which can be viewed as a stochastic numerical method for the Boltzmann equation, were also employed to study the velocity slip problem. Actually, this nontrivial phenomenon was well-accepted only after it was confirmed by the DSMC results.11

Recently, the molecular dynamics (MD) method, the third approach, has also been adopted to investigate the velocity slip and velocity inversion.13,14 Unlike the direct solution of Boltzmann equation and the DSMC methods in which the boundary condition depends on the accommodation coefficient, in MD simulations no explicit velocity boundary conditions are employed; instead, the slip at the surface depends on the strength of the fluid–solid interactions. Jung13 applied the MD to a nanometer cylindrical Couette flow, and found that the velocity slip and consequently velocity inversion occurred as the fluid-wall interaction near the outer cylinder was weak and the fluid density was low.

The three approaches mentioned above are standard methods in fluid dynamics and each of them has its limitations. The Navier–Stokes equations are limited to near-continuum flows; the DSMC and MD methods usually suffer from expensive computational costs and the direct solution of the Boltzmann equation using the finite-difference method is also limited to simple flows.

The Lattice Boltzmann Equation (LBE) is a discrete kinetic scheme which emerged about two decades ago. Originally LBE was recognized as an improvement of the lattice gas automata,15 but later it was shown that LBE can be derived systemically from the Boltzmann equation and therefore LBE is essentially a numerical scheme for solving the Boltzmann equation.16–18 The LBE method has gained much success in the past in a variety of fields.19 However, the study and applications of LBE for micro-scale flows did not appear until 2002.20,21 After that, numerous works have been published on this subject.22 However, most of the available works, if not all, only considered flows with flat walls. Therefore, these methods cannot be directly applied to the cylindrical Couette flow and consequently journal bearings. In this article, an LBE method is proposed for the numerical simulation of macro and micro flows with curved walls. The proposed method is then applied to macro and micro journal bearings to investigate the pressure distribution.

In addition, Lee et al.7 demonstrated that the slip flow effect becomes significant with temperature increase as well as the lower range of bearing numbers. Zhang et al.23 analyzed the characteristics of gas-lubricated journal micro bearings based on the effective viscosity according to the first-order slip velocity boundary. Therefore, it is also necessary to predict and analyze the performance of gas-lubricated journal micro bearings under high-order slip effects for the applications in micro-rotating machinery. To make a profound understanding of the properties and performance of micro bearings in MEMS, we have based our micro-scale simulations on the second-order slip boundary condition. In this article, ‘LBE method for macro and micro flows with a curved wall’ section provides numerical analyses. The numerical results and discussion of the pressure distributions are presented in ‘Results and discussion’ section. Final section draws some brief conclusions.

sec.title: LBE method for macro and micro flows with a curved wall
sec.p: Unlike the Navier–Stokes equations that govern the pressure and velocity in fluids, the Boltzmann equation governs a particle distribution function f(x, v, t), which depends on space x, particle velocity v and time t. When Kn « 1, the fluid behaves as a continuum and can be modeled by using the macroscopic equations of flow. It has been shown that, in the limit of a small Knudsen number, the Navier–Stokes equations can be recovered from the Boltzmann equation if the Chapman–Enskog expansion is used.

Since the gas is compressible in micro flows, the Reynolds equation, which describes the pressure distribution in the gas-lubricated journal micro bearing, has strong nonlinearity and is difficult to be solved mathematically. The LBM is used in this study to obtain bearing pressure distribution. The advantage of the Boltzmann method comes from the fact that they have been proven to be as accurate as finite difference and finite element numerical schemes.

The LBE describes the evolution of a set of discrete velocity distribution functions as follows (1) where fi(x, t) is the distribution function associated with the gas molecules moving with the discrete velocity ci at position x and time t, Ωi(f) is the discrete collision operator, δt is the time step, and k is the number of discrete velocities. The most widely used LBE model is the so-called Lattice–Bhatnagar–Gross–Krook (LBGK) model. It is famous as single relaxation time method, where the collision operator is given by (2)Ωi=-fi(x→,t)-fi eq(x→,t)τ Here fi eq is the equilibrium distribution function which depends on the gas density, velocity and temperature and is defined as follows (3)fo eq=49ρ[1-32U2C2] (4)fi eq=19ρ[1+3ci·Uc2+92(ci·U)2c4-32U2c2]i=1,2,3,4 (5)fi eq=136ρ[1+3ci·Uc2+92(ci·U)2c4-32U2c2]i=5,6,7,8 where ci are the model-dependent weight coefficients, cs = RT (R is the gas constant and T is the temperature) is related to the sound speed; for isothermal flows cs appears as a parameter and is determined by the lattice speed c = δx/δt, where δx and δt are the lattice spacing and time step, respectively. In equations (3) to (5), the density ρ and velocity u of the fluid are defined as the zeroth and first-order moments of fi, respectively (6)ρ=∑i=0 kfi ρu=∑i=0 kcifi

The LBGK models have been widely used in many fields. However, some recent studies demonstrate that such models have some limitations for micro flows.22,24 The main disadvantage of the LBGK model for micro flows lies in the boundary condition. It is known from kinetic theory that the slip velocity depends only on the Knudsen number Kn and the gas-wall interaction. In the LBGK model, however, it also depends on the value of the dimensionless relaxation time τ,22,24 which can be changed with grid resolution for a given Kn. This means that, the LBGK model contains some non-physical numerical artifacts in addition to the physical part. On the other hand, an LBE model with a multiple-relaxation-time (MRT) collision operator can remove this artifact by choosing the relaxation times properly. Therefore, an MRT model is employed here which is defined by (7)Ωi(f)=-∑j(M-1SM)ij[fj-fj (eq)] M is a b × b transform matrix that projects fi onto the moment space m = Mf, with f = (f0, f1,…, fq–1)T and S = diag(τ0, τ1,…, τq–1)−1. The MRT-LBE can also be expressed in a vector form as (8)f(x+cδt,t+δt)-f(x,t)=M-1S[m-m(eq)] where m(eq) = Mf (eq). It is obvious from equation (8) that τi represents the relaxation time of the i-th moment mi as it approaches to its equilibrium mi(eq) due to collision. It should be noted that MRT model reduces to the LBGK model as τi = τ. In the present work, we consider the two-dimensional nine-velocity (D2Q9) model where the discrete velocities ci are defined by (9)

The weights in fi(eq) are given by (10) and cs=RT=c/3. Without loss of generality, we take c as the velocity unit. There are different choices for the transform matrix M, and here we take the one proposed in Lallemand and Luo25 (11)M=[111111111-4-1-1-1-122224-2-2-2-21111010-101-1-110-20201-1-110010-111-1-100-20211-1-101-11-10000000001-11-1]

The corresponding discrete velocity moments of the distribution functions are (12)m=(ρ,e,ɛ,ρux,qx,ρuy,qy,pxx,pxy)T which have clear physical significance.25 The relaxation matrix corresponding to the nine moments is (13)S=diag(τρ,τe,τɛ,τj,τq,τj,τq,τs,τs)-1 where τρ and τj can take any value since ρ and ρu are conserved variables during the evolution. In order to simulate micro flows, the mean-free-path of the gas λ should be incorporated into LBE. This can be achieved by noticing that λ is related to the viscosity as follows26 (14)λ=ρvpπRT2
Therefore, the relaxation time τs can be determined by λ (15)τS=12+6πλδx

Another key issue in simulating micro flows with LBE is the suitable specification of boundary conditions. For continuum flows the bounce-back scheme can be used to realize the no-slip boundary condition. However, for micro flows this simple boundary condition does not work in that velocity slip occurs at wall. Previously, some kinetic boundary conditions have been proposed for micro flows with flat walls,27,28 and a detailed analysis has been presented in Guo and Zheng.22 However, most of those available boundary conditions are not suitable for flows with curved walls. For example, both the bounce-back-specular reflection and discrete-Maxwell-diffuse schemes, which are the two most widely used boundary conditions in LBE for micro flows, are nonlocal due to the involving of the specular reflection. This will bring some difficulties when they are applied to curved walls.

sec.title: Bounce-back boundary condition
sec.p:
Bounce-back boundary condition is used for the simulation of macro journal bearings. In the half-way bounce-back boundary condition, the real physical wall is in the middle of two lattice nodes. When this boundary condition is applied, the unknown distribution functions in the wall will be replaced with the distribution functions that enter the wall with the counter direction. In this method the boundary nodes will not be calculated in the collision step, thus a semi-wall between two last nodes of lattice will be obtained (Figure 1), therefore (16)fi out(xb,t)=fi out(xnb,t) where i and I~ are in opposite directions. Define ei as the lattice velocities that enter the computational domain and ei as the velocities which leave it. The left-hand side of equation (16) refers to post-collision distribution function, xb is the boundary node location and xnb is the location of near boundary nodes. So we have (17)xnb=xb+eiδt Figure 1.
Bounce-back boundary condition.

In the streaming step the distribution functions of near boundary nodes become definite with boundary condition, thus (18)fi in(xnb,t+1)=fi out(xb,t) Finally, using equations (16) and (18), we have (19)fi in(xnb,t+1)=fi~ out(xnb,t)

sec.title: Diffuse-bounce-back boundary condition
sec.p:
In order to simulate a micro flow with curved walls, we propose a boundary condition that involves only local computations. First, we approximate a curved surface with some points locating at the middle of the links across the wall, as shown in Figure 2. We call the node occupied by fluid a boundary node if at least one of its eight neighbors is covered by the wall, or in other words, one of its links crosses the physical boundary. Obviously, the zigzag ghost boundary can properly approximate the physical one if the lattice is fine enough. Such a treatment has been widely used in LBE, and its reliability has been confirmed in many previous studies.29,30 Figure 2.
Approximation of a curved boundary. Filled circle: boundary node with at least a neighbor node covered by the solid wall; Open circle: solid node with at least a node occupied by fluid; Filled square: mid-point of the link between a fluid nod and solid node. Solid line: Physical boundary; Dashed line: Ghost boundary.

With such an approximation, we now consider how to specify the unknown distribution functions at the boundary nodes. As it is shown in Figure 2, for the boundary node xb whose neighboring node xb+Ci~(Ci~=-ci) is covered by the wall, we propose the following diffuse-bounce-back (DBB) boundary condition to specify the unknown distribution function fi(xb, t + δt) (20) where ρb = ρ(xb, t), uw is the wall velocity at the wall node xw, and f~(xb, t) is the post-collision distribution function defined by (21)f~(xb,t)=f~(xb,t)-M-1S[m(xb,t)-m(eq)(xb,t)]

The DBB boundary condition (20) is a combination of the bounce-back scheme and the Maxwell diffuse scheme, which was first proposed in Verhaeghe et al.24 for flat fully diffusive fixed walls. The DBB boundary condition is indeed an extension of the original scheme proposed in Verhaeghe et al.24 to the curved moving walls. This scheme has a clear physical picture: as the post-collision populations arrive at the wall node, some of them are bounced back directly, and others hit the wall and reach the equilibrium state immediately with the wall velocity and temperature, and then are reflected back. The main advantage of this scheme is that only ci and Ci~ are involved so that the computation is completely local, which is a perfect feature for curved walls in comparison with bounce back boundary condition.

In the DBB scheme, the parameter r plays the vital role and has a direct influence on the slip velocity at the boundary. For flat walls, r was determined according to a first-order slip boundary condition.24 Here we define r in more general cases. Since, it is difficult to analyze the DBB boundary condition for a general flow with curved walls; we consider a simple case, i.e. the force-driven Poiseuille flow between two parallel plates, which has also been used in some previous studies.22,24,31–33 Following the procedure in Guo and Zheng,22 we can obtain the slip velocity at the wall; r and τq should be set as follows in order to realize the boundary condition (20) with the DBB scheme (22)r=6π-L(1)6π+L(1) τq=4πL(1)(τS-12)2+316(τS-12)

Although the above results are obtained based on the planar Poiseuille flow, they may also be applied to general cases involving curved walls if the velocity profile in the near-wall region is assumed to be a local second-order polynomial. This assumption is reasonable and has been adopted in some previous studies. For example, Ginzburg and d'Humiéres developed a set of boundary conditions where the parameters are set based on the analysis of the Poiseuille flow,31 and Pan et al.34 has shown that when these boundary conditions are applied to flows in porous media with different structures, the results are rather satisfactory.

sec.title: A simple cavitation algorithm
sec.p: A cavitation algorithm in bearings has to impose the Reynolds conditions at the boundary of the cavitation region, i.e. p = pcav and ∂p/∂x=0, where typically pcav = 0 (gage). Since in LBM the pressure is related to density by p = cs2ρ, the cavitation pressure can be defined as pcav = cs2 ρ0. This implies that the constraint p ≥ pcav, which has to be satisfied throughout the film in order to avoid cavitation, can be written as (23)ρ≥ρ0=pcavcs2

As it will be shown in the next section, the results provided by the current cavitation model are in good agreement with those obtained using the finite element algorithm presented by Goenka. The algorithm is simple to implement while the computational effort is practically the same as in the case of the common LBGK implementation.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: In this section, first a cavitation case is simulated for the macro journal bearing and the results are compared with a finite element cavitation algorithm. Second, a micro journal bearing is studied; the diagrams of non-dimensional pressure in different Kn numbers are gained and the results are compared with the results of collocation method.

sec.title: Infinitely long journal bearing
sec.p: The one-dimensional analytic solution of the Reynolds equation for an infinitely long journal bearing of radius R provides the pressure distribution as a function of the angular coordinate θ (24)p(θ)=6μωR2ɛC2(2+ɛcosθ)sinθ(2+ɛ2)(1+ɛcosθ)2 where C is the clearance, ε is the eccentricity, and ω is the angular speed. The LBGK simulations are carried out for a test journal bearing with R = 0.05 m, C = 100 µm, and ε = 0.3. The Reynolds number is 267 while the Mach number is 0.12, such that the incompressible form of the LBM method is justified. Taking oil as the working fluid, then cavitation is expected and the cavitation algorithm presented in the previous section is used for the simulations.

For oil with density of ρ0 = 870 kg/m3, the resulting speed of sound is cs = 1313 m/s. The dynamic viscosity of the oil is μ = 0.05 kg/m/s, and the journal rotational speed is set to 1000 r/min. The LBGK results of pressure distribution inside the cavitated journal bearing are compared against the simulations performed using finite element method35 in Figure 3. Figure 3 shows very close agreement between the results of LBGK model and the results of finite element algorithm. Figure 3.
Pressure distribution inside a cavitated journal bearing (n = 1000 r/min), comparison between the LBGK model and finite element algorithm.
LBGK: Lattice–Bhatnagar–Gross–Krook.

sec.title: Property analysis in journal micro bearings
sec.p:
The pressure distribution is the static property, which represents intended steady-state operating condition and is the important design specification of gas-lubricated journal micro bearings in MEMS. Pressure distribution is used for modeling micro-gas bearings. Accurate computation of the static pressure distribution, for a finite L/D with allowance for the slip effect, is one of the necessary preliminaries to ensure that the bearing can safely operate in a steady state. The static pressure distribution is computed using the DBB boundary condition. The effect of Knudsen number on the pressure distribution is investigated. Figures 4 to 6 show the pressure distributions of the gas-lubricated journal bearing under different Knudsen numbers with ε = 0.3. The film pressure decreases with increase in the Knudsen number. Figure 4.
Pressure distribution of the bearing under Knudsen number Kn = 0.001. Figure 5.
Pressure distribution of the bearing under Knudsen number Kn = 0.05. Figure 6.
Pressure distribution of the bearing under Knudsen number Kn = 0.1.

The two cylinders are both assumed to be fully diffusive, i.e. σ1 = σ2 = σ = 1.0. In the simulation, we set λ = 1.0 and ω = 0.001. The DBB boundary condition is applied to the two cylinder surfaces according to equation (20) with L(1) = (2 – σ)/2. The relaxation times τs and τq are determined from equations (15) and (22), respectively. The other two free relaxation times, τe and τε, are found to have little influence on the results, and we set them to be 1.1 and 1.2, respectively. It can be seen that the LBE predictions are in good quantitative agreement with the predictions of spectral collocation method.36 The small discrepancy in the numerical results can be attributed to two factors. First, the smooth cylinder surfaces are replaced by some rough zigzag segments, and the approximation error decreases with decreasing δx. Second, the parameter r in the DBB boundary condition and the relaxation time τq are determined according to the results for a flat wall, and thus the accuracy for a curved wall depends on the local curvature of the surface. Despite these intrinsic errors of the present method, the agreement between the LBE results and those of the spectral collocation method are satisfactory.36
The present study also indicates that the proposed LBE can serve as an effective tool for other micro-scale flows with curved walls.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The LBM can be used for lubrication problems involving complex geometries which have to be considered for problems that present departures from the thin-film assumption. The method is more convenient to implement than traditional (Navier–Stokes based) CFD methods. In the present work LBM is tested for simple configurations but its application to more complex, three-dimensional problems is similar.

The simple LBGK cavitation algorithm presented in this work is convenient for incipient cavitation of macro bearings and is comparable with well-established finite element cavitation algorithms. From an implementation point of view, the present cavitation algorithm does not significantly increase the complexity of the code and the computational time. The computational effort required by the LBM simulations is far larger than that of either the traditional Navier–Stokes solvers or the finite element solver used for the cavitation.

The performance of the gas-lubricated journal micro bearings in MEMS is also investigated. The second-order slip boundary condition is considered. The static property of the micro bearing, which is pressure distribution is analyzed and discussed under the effect of Knudsen number. The film pressure decreases with increase in the Knudsen number. This indicates that the slip-flow boundary condition enhances the good performance of the gas-lubricated journal bearing-rotor system.
